tweets.text:
A painter with no commission walked into the 1787 Paris Salon and ended another man’s career with a single canvas.

Peyron (left) was hired to paint The Death of Socrates. David (right) painted his own version anyway. Uninvited. Same scene. Same year.

Look at what David does. Socrates reaches for the poison cup mid-sentence. Everyone around him is falling apart. One man can’t even look.

Socrates isn’t dying yet. He’s still teaching. David paints him like someone who’s already won the argument.

David’s painting destroyed Peyron’s reputation overnight. Critics barely mentioned the commissioned version.

Two years later, the Revolution. David sat in the National Convention and voted to execute King Louis XVI.

Peyron died broke in 1814. Nobody remembers his painting.

Jacques-Louis David, The Death of Socrates, 1787. The Met.

posts.title: Damascus Room
posts.medium: Wood, paint, gold leaf, stone, glass, plaster
posts.dimensions: 22 ft 2 in. × 16 ft 8½ in. × 11 ft 5 in.

tweets.text:
There’s a room in the Met that’s 5,700 miles from the house it belongs to.

Built in Damascus in 1707. Carved wood panels, painted flowers, gold leaf, Quranic inscriptions running the full perimeter. 22 feet long.

In 1934, a dealer dismantled it and shipped it to New York in pieces. It sat in crates for decades before the Met reassembled it. Not a replica. The actual room.

The most reproduced image in history was made by a 70-year-old who considered everything before it worthless.

Hokusai had been drawing waves since he was 37. Thirty-three years of attempts. None were right.

It’s one of Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji. Fuji appears in every print. Here it’s the tiny triangle in the background about to be swallowed.

This is another from the same series: fishing boats at Choshi. Same ocean, same mountain, completely different mood.

The original woodblock was pressed thousands of times. Only a few hundred copies survive.

Left: Met Museum. Right: Art Institute of Chicago. Same print, same woodblock. You can see how the ink and pressure varied between impressions.

Katsushika Hokusai, The Great Wave, ca. 1831.

The most famous American painting was made in Germany by a German.

Emanuel Leutze painted this in Dusseldorf in 1851, using the Rhine as a stand-in for the Delaware. Almost everything is wrong. The flag didn’t exist yet. The crossing was at midnight in a snowstorm. The boats are the wrong type. Washington was 44, not the old man shown here.

Leutze didn’t care. He painted it during the 1848 European revolutions. He wanted to show Germans what a successful revolution looked like. It’s 21 feet wide.

posts.title: The Unicorn Rests in a Garden

tweets.text:
Nobody knows who made The Unicorn Tapestries. 520 years old. Woven from wool, silk, silver, and gold thread. We don’t know the artist, the patron, or why they were made.

They turned up in the 1850s in a barn in the French countryside, covering potatoes to keep them from freezing. 12-foot tapestries woven with gold thread. Potato covers.

Rockefeller bought them in 1922. They hang in The Cloisters, a medieval monastery the Met built on the northern tip of Manhattan.

Aztec gold lip plug, 1400s. A labret is a piercing worn below the lower lip. This one is shaped like a serpent about to strike.

The tongue is articulated. It actually moves. When the wearer talked or moved their jaw, the snake’s tongue flicked back and forth.

Only the emperor and highest nobles could wear one. In Aztec society, labrets marked who had the right to speak and be heard. 2½ inches long. Solid gold. 600 years old.

In 1886, a family tomb was found at Deir el-Medina in Egypt, completely intact. 3,000 years and nobody had touched it. It belonged to the workers who built the pharaohs’ tombs.

This is a mummy board, a carved wooden cover placed directly over the wrapped body inside the coffin. It shows Iineferty, wife of Sennedjem, a foreman who painted the walls of the Valley of the Kings.

Carved around 1250 BC. The braided wig, the pleated gown, the lotus on her forehead. Not royalty. A craftsman’s wife. It survived longer than every dynasty that followed.

Italian armet, ca. 1440. The first helmet that fully enclosed a knight’s head while being light enough to fight in.

Two cheek-pieces hinge open like doors. You put your head in, snap them shut, lock the visor down. 7 pounds. Breathing through slots barely wider than a coin.

This is what it took to survive the 15th century.

posts.title: Field Armor of King Henry VIII

tweets.text:
Henry VIII ordered this armor for his last military campaign. He was 53, so crippled by gout he needed a crane to lift him onto his horse.

50 pounds of Italian steel, custom-built in 1544 to fit a body that could barely walk.

Six wives, two beheadings, a break with Rome, and you can read the whole story in the waistline.

Three of this hippo’s legs were snapped off on purpose. By the people who buried it 4,000 years ago.

Ancient Egyptians believed tomb figurines could come alive in the afterlife. Hippos killed more people than crocodiles. So they broke its legs first.

His name is William. A British officer named him in 1931 in a Punch magazine story about a print of this hippo hanging in his living room.

The name stuck. 8 inches long. Nearly 4,000 years old. The Met’s unofficial mascot.

Egyptian, ca. 1961-1878 B.C. Faience. The Met.

X-rays of this Caravaggio revealed a painting underneath.

The figure on the far left? Originally had wings and a quiver of arrows. He was Cupid. Caravaggio painted over him, turning a god into a regular boy reaching for grapes.

Look closely at the original. You can still see traces of the wings under the surface.

The X-ray makes the wings and quiver much clearer.

He was 26. This was his audition for Cardinal Del Monte, his first major patron. The central figure with the lute looks directly at you. Some scholars think it’s Caravaggio’s own face.

He painted himself into his audition tape and buried a god under a few layers of oil paint.

Caravaggio, The Musicians, 1597. The Met.

posts.title: Rolltop Desk
posts.medium: Oak, cherry, mahogany, 10+ woods; mother-of-pearl; gilt bronze

tweets.text:
This desk has more secret compartments than most spy movies.

Turn the key: side drawers spring open. Press a hidden button under each one and they swing aside, revealing more drawers behind them.

David Roentgen, 1776. Marie Antoinette and Catherine the Great both ordered his furniture.

Pull out the writing surface and the rolltop automatically retracts. Behind the bronze plaque? A reading stand with built-in inkwell that unfolds at the turn of a key.

A dozen different woods. Mother-of-pearl inlay. Every surface does something.

David Roentgen, ca. 1776. The Met.

The king is the smallest figure. That’s the point.

Olowe of Ise carved this 5-foot post from a single log for the palace of the Ogoga of Ikere, a Yoruba king in southwestern Nigeria, around 1910. The king sits at center, crowned. His senior wife towers behind him. She’s the one who placed the crown on his head.

Five figures, one log, zero seams.

This brass head sat on an altar in the royal palace of the Kingdom of Benin, a powerful state in what is now southern Nigeria. Not the modern country of Benin. A different place entirely.

A newly crowned king would commission one to honor the previous ruler. A carved ivory tusk fit into the top. This one dates to the 1700s or early 1800s.

In 1897, British troops invaded Benin City and looted thousands of objects from palace shrines. This head passed through a German collector, a New York dealer, and Christie’s before Chicago’s Art Institute bought it in 2003.

Before the katana, there was the ken.

Straight. Double-edged. Based on Chinese swords that crossed the sea centuries earlier. This one is from the 5th century, 700 years before samurai culture produced the curved blades everyone pictures.

It was buried in a kofun, an ancient Japanese tomb mound built for rulers and warriors. The Met received it in 1906 in a direct exchange with the Imperial Museum in Tokyo.

1,500 years old. 12.6 ounces.

You’d walk right past this. It looks like a candlestick.

It’s a compound microscope. Three convex lenses hidden inside. Unscrew the ornamental finial on top and the fancy decorative bit IS the lens cap.

Claude-Simeon Passemant built it around 1750. He was Louis XV’s personal instrument maker, living inside the Louvre. The tube is wrapped in stingray skin. About 10 survive.

At Versailles, even your lab equipment had to match the furniture.

A nautilus shell from the Indian Ocean. A silver-gilt sea monster from Delft, a Dutch city famous for its craftsmen. A goddess perched on top.

Dutch merchants brought these shells back from the spice routes in the early 1600s. Silversmiths turned them into drinking vessels no one would ever drink from.

Made in 1607. Only five others from this period survive. The Rothschild family owned this one. Christie’s sold it in 2023. The Cleveland Museum of Art bought it that year.

From the ocean floor to Ohio. Over 400 years.

This sword has no point. It was never meant to stab anyone.

Executioner’s sword, 1634. The flat, blunt tip is the giveaway. Designed for one motion only. Two-handed grip, downward swing.

No point meant no thrusting. Short cross-guards because you didn’t need hand protection. Many had inscriptions. Prayers, mostly. “When I raise this sword, I wish this poor sinner receives eternal life.”

Last sword execution in Europe: Switzerland, 1868.
